channel.title: California
channel.description: California news and features from the Los Angeles Times.

item.title: Monrovia, Duarte, other foothill cities alert to threat from wind-driven Bobcat fire
item.dc:creator: Hayley Smith, Joseph Serna
item.description: Monrovia, Duarte and other foothill cities are on alert as winds threaten to send the Bobcat fire toward homes.
item.content:encoded: Monrovia, Duarte and other foothill cities are on alert as winds threaten to send the Bobcat fire toward homes.

media:content.media:description: SAN GABRIEL MOUNTAINS, CA - SEPTEMBER 08: Bureau of Land Management fire hotshot crew Aravaipa huddle to plan their attack k on Bobcat fire along Highway 39 West Fork on Tuesday, Sept. 8, 2020 in San Gabriel Mountains, CA. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Gang members went to wrong home in fatal Halloween party shooting, police say
item.dc:creator: James Queally
item.description: A dozen people are arrested in connection with a 2019 shooting at a Halloween party at the wrong home in Long Beach, police say.
item.content:encoded: A dozen people are arrested in connection with a 2019 shooting at a Halloween party at the wrong home in Long Beach, police say.

media:content.media:description: Family and friends of shooting victims are joined by government officials on Nov. 5 during a traditional Buddhist memorial ceremony in the backyard of a home in Long Beach where three people were killed Halloween night.

item.title: Deputies fire projectiles into crowd during third night of Dijon Kizzee protests
item.dc:creator: Hayley Smith
item.description: Authorities say no one was injured when L.A. County sheriff's deputies fired projectiles into a crowd protesting the fatal shooting of Dijon Kizzee.
item.content:encoded: Authorities say no one was injured when L.A. County sheriff's deputies fired projectiles into a crowd protesting the fatal shooting of Dijon Kizzee.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGLES, CA - SEPTEMBER 05: People use a car for cover after deputies fired non-lethal weapons at the crowd during a protest for Dijon Kizzee at theSouth Los Angeles County Sheriff's office on Saturday, Sept. 5, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. The demonstration was held to hold the L.A. County Sheriff's Department accountable for the death of 29-year-old Dijon Kizzee whole was fatally by deputies after being stopped for an alleged vehicle code violation while biking on Aug. 30. (Josie Norris / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 'Gimme Shelter': Why the bid to allow duplexes in California's single-family home neighborhoods failed

item.title: California begins sending extra $900 to those unemployed due to COVID-19
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy
item.description: California officials will mark the Labor Day holiday by sending a $900 supplemental unemployment benefit to jobless residents.
item.content:encoded: California officials will mark the Labor Day holiday by sending a $900 supplemental unemployment benefit to jobless residents.

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this July 20, 2010 file photo, people arrive to seek employment opportunities at a JobTrain office in Menlo Park, Calif. On Monday, Aug. 24, 2020, Employment Development Department Director Sharon Hilliard told California lawmakers in Sacramento, California, the state has more than 1 million pending claims for unemployment benefits. Hilliard called the situation "shameful," but said the department is working through the backlog. (AP Photo/Paul Sakuma, File)

item.dc:creator: George Skelton
item.description: Assemblywoman Buffy Wicks (D-Oakland) leaped from rookie legislator to rising star literally overnight after bringing her newborn baby to the Assembly floor when she was denied the ability to vote remotely.

item.title: Los Angeles coronavirus toll declines, but officials warn of possible holiday spike
item.dc:creator: Gale Holland
item.description: Health officials confirmed five new deaths and 798 new cases of COVID-19 in Los Angeles County, continuing a steady decline in the region's pandemic toll.
item.content:encoded: Health officials confirmed five new deaths and 798 new cases of COVID-19 in Los Angeles County, continuing a steady decline in the region's pandemic toll.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MARCH 04 , 2020 - L.A. County Department of Public Health Director Barbara Ferrer addresses a press conference held at the steps of Kenneth Hahn Hall of Administration to declare a health emergency as the number of coronavirus cases increased to seven, with six new cases in Los Angeles County. None of the new cases are connected to "community spread," officials said. All individuals were exposed to COVID-19 through close contacts. The additional cases were confirmed Tuesday night. Officials said three of the new cases were travelers who had visited northern Italy, two were family members who had close contact with someone outside of the county who was infected, and one had a job that put them in contact with travelers. One person has been hospitalized, and the others are isolated at home. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Irfan Khan/Irfan Khan/Irfan Khan/Los Angeles Times

item.title: All-time record heat across Southern California fuels fires, threatens power supply
item.dc:creator: Jaclyn Cosgrove, Alex Wigglesworth, Laura Newberry, Sammy Roth
item.description: Blackouts could take place during peak evening hours, 5 to 9 p.m., according to the California Independent System Operator, which runs the power grid for much of the state.
item.content:encoded: Blackouts could take place during peak evening hours, 5 to 9 p.m., according to the California Independent System Operator, which runs the power grid for much of the state.

media:content.media:description: LONG BEACH, CA - SEP. 4, 2020. A blazing sun silhouettes power lines in North Long Beach ahead of a heatwave that is forecast to begin on Saturday, Sept. 5, 2020. The weather event has the potential to set all-time record hot temperatures throughout Southern California through the Labor Day weekend. (Luis Sinco / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Mojave Desert fire in August destroyed the heart of a beloved Joshua tree forest
item.dc:creator: Bettina Boxall
item.description: Wildfire burned one of the world's largest forests of Joshua trees, charring more than 1.3 million trees. The 43,273 acres of the Dome fire are forever transformed.
item.content:encoded: Wildfire burned one of the world's largest forests of Joshua trees, charring more than 1.3 million trees. The 43,273 acres of the Dome fire are forever transformed.

media:content.media:description: CIMA, CA - SEPTEMBER 01: Jacob "JT" Sohr, engine captain National Park Service, center, dwarfed by massive expanse of charred section of Mojave National Preserve. The Dome fire, one of the hundreds of wildfires that erupted during California's lightning siege, scorched 43,000 acres in the Mojave National Preserve, incinerating parts of the world's largest Joshua tree forest Mojave National Preserve on Tuesday, Sept. 1, 2020 in Cima, CA. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: For L.A. Latinos, Whittier Boulevard is still a crossroads of change and hope
item.dc:creator: Priscella Vega
item.description: For decades, Whittier Boulevard has been a hub of Latino life. Now the 14-mile thoroughfare is facing challenges from the pandemic and gentrification.
item.content:encoded: For decades, Whittier Boulevard has been a hub of Latino life. Now the 14-mile thoroughfare is facing challenges from the pandemic and gentrification.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUG. 18, 2020. The sun sets on Whittier Boulevard in East Los Angeles, which has served as a hub of Latino life, commerce and culture for decades. The affordable shopping district and surrounding neighborhoods was fertile ground for an emerging, immigrant-rich middle class. Today, the heart of Whittier Blvd., from Atlantic Avenue on the west to Eastern Avenue on the east, is facing a new host of challenges from the coronavirus pandemic, economic meltdown and creeping gentrification. For many, this faded but resilient avenue remains a crossroads of change and hope. (Luis Sinco / Los Angeles Times)

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MARCH 04 , 2020 - L.A. County Department of Public Health Director Barbara Ferrer addresses a press conference held at the steps of Kenneth Hahn Hall of Administration to declare a health emergency as the number of coronavirus cases increased to seven, with six new cases in Los Angeles County. None of the new cases are connected to "community spread," officials said. All individuals were exposed to COVID-19 through close contacts. The additional cases were confirmed Tuesday night. Officials said three of the new cases were travelers who had visited northern Italy, two were family members who had close contact with someone outside of the county who was infected, and one had a job that put them in contact with travelers. One person has been hospitalized, and the others are isolated at home. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Fire, smoke, heat, drought â how climate change could spoil your next glass of California Cabernet
item.dc:creator: Steve Lopez
item.description: How many more scorched summers can the king grape of Napa Valley survive?
item.content:encoded: How many more scorched summers can the king grape of Napa Valley survive?

media:content.media:description: San Juan Bautista, California,-Aug. 12, 2020-Tending so some young Grenache Nour vines, Randall Grahm is founder of Bonny Doon Vineyard. He is perhaps best known for his pioneering work with Rhone varietals in California. As the earth continues to heat up, and water tables decrease, hearty varieties of grapes will be important. (Carolyn Cole/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Column: Is President Trump right? Are Democrats destroying our cities and states?
item.dc:creator: Steve Lopez
item.description: Trump's attack on Democrats ignores a few uncomfortable truths about his own actions and inactions.
item.content:encoded: Trump's attack on Democrats ignores a few uncomfortable truths about his own actions and inactions.

media:content.media:description: HOLLYWOOD, CA - JUNE 14, 2020 - - Thousands participate in the All Black Lives Matter solidarity march to mark LGBTQ Pride Month along Hollywood Blvd. in Hollywood on June 14, 2020. The march also honored Tony McDade, a transgender man killed by Tallahassee Police Department officers on May 27. The march is in solidarity with the Black Lives Matter movement and highlight the contributions of people of color who were instrumental in organizing the LGBT movement, such as Marsha P. Johnson and Sylvia Rivera. The procession started on Hollywood Boulevard at Highland Avenue in Hollywood. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: L.A. teachers union opposes opening campuses for students with disabilities, English learners
item.dc:creator: Howard Blume
item.description: The L.A. teachers union on Friday announced that it opposes the return to campus of students with special needs â saying it isn't safe yet. And the union says schools can't bring teachers back without its approval.

item.title: Controversy over USC professor's use of Chinese word that sounds like racial slur in English
item.dc:creator: Nina Agrawal
item.description: A USC professor was asked to step away from teaching his class after students complained that an example he gave in Mandarin sounded like a racial slur.
item.content:encoded: A USC professor was asked to step away from teaching his class after students complained that an example he gave in Mandarin sounded like a racial slur.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUGUST 17, 2020 - - A lone student walks across an empty section of the USC campus on the first day of academic instruction for the Fall 2020 semester in Los Angeles on August 17, 2020. Students were taking online courses due to the coronavirus pandemic and the campus was nearly empty. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 'A forgotten city': An L.A. community beset by police violence and crime hopes for change
item.dc:creator: Nicole Santa Cruz, Ruben Vives
item.description: The small neighborhood of Westmont is in the spotlight after two police shootings there this year. But residents want officials bring something to the community they think is missing: a message of hope.
item.content:encoded: The small neighborhood of Westmont is in the spotlight after two police shootings there this year. But residents want officials bring something to the community they think is missing: a message of hope.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - SEP. 1, 2020. Relatives and friends of Dijon Kizzee gather Tuesday, Sept. 1, 2020, at the site near the intersection of W. 109th Place and S. Budlong Avenue, where the 29-year-old Black man was shot and killed by L.A. County Sheriff's deputies. The shootting of Kizzee on Monday afternoon, Aug. 31, 2020, resulted in a standoff between protesters and police that continued into the night. (Luis Sinco / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: To curb sex trafficking, prosecutors forbid Pomona motel from renting rooms by the hour
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: The Los Angeles County district attorney's office said a settlement with a motel in an area of Pomona beset with prostitution represents the first time county prosecutors have used consumer protection laws to target sex trafficking.
item.content:encoded: The Los Angeles County district attorney's office said a settlement with a motel in an area of Pomona beset with prostitution represents the first time county prosecutors have used consumer protection laws to target sex trafficking.

media:content.media:description: L.A. County District Attorney Jackie Lacey announces the creation of the Conviction Review Unit during a press conference at the Hall of Justice in downtown Los Angeles.

item.title: Reports of man flying in jet pack near LAX prompt FBI call for public's help
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton
item.description: Reports of man flying jet pack near LAX prompt FBI call for public's help
item.content:encoded: Reports of man flying jet pack near LAX prompt FBI call for public's help

media:content.media:description: The airport can be a jungle, so plan ahead.

item.title: L.A. County reports 3 more children sickened with coronavirus-linked syndrome
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: Los Angeles County officials also reported an additional 47 deaths related to COVID-19 and 1,439 new cases.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles County officials also reported an additional 47 deaths related to COVID-19 and 1,439 new cases.

media:content.media:description: ANAHEIM, CALIFORNIA-JULY 11, 2020-A test kit is passed through the car window at the Anaheim Convention Center. Orange County residents will be able to get tested at no cost for COVID-19 at the Anaheim Convention Center starting today, July 15, 2020. Clinicians from 360 Clinic are administering the test kits, but citizens will do their own sample taking. (Carolyn Cole/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Sentenced to life as a teen, Compton man to be freed after evidence is questioned
item.dc:creator: James Queally
item.description: A Compton man who has spent nearly 20 years in prison for a shooting will be released after questions were raised about the evidence against him.
item.content:encoded: A Compton man who has spent nearly 20 years in prison for a shooting will be released after questions were raised about the evidence against him.

media:content.media:description: Emon Barnes, seen here as a teenager, was convicted of attempted murder in a Compton shooting at the age of 15. Attorneys from Loyola Marymount University's Project for the Innocence and L.A. County prosecutors teamed up to arrange for his release from San Quentin prison after questions were raised about the evidence against him.

item.title: Beach cities brace for crowds ahead of Labor Day weekend heat wave
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: With the holiday coinciding with a heat wave, Southern California's coastal communities are bracing for an influx of visitors.
item.content:encoded: With the holiday coinciding with a heat wave, Southern California's coastal communities are bracing for an influx of visitors.

media:content.media:description: Laura Martinez, 8, of Santa Ana, plays in spray pool to cool off as hundreds of people spread out over Mile Square Park to celebrate Labor Day with their families and got relief from the heat wave Monday, Sept. 7, 2020 in Fountain Valley.

item.title: USPS mail is found dumped at two spots in Glendale, prompting investigation
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: Piles of unopened mail and packages were discovered at two locations near each other Thursday morning in Glendale. It is unclear whether the incidents are related.
item.content:encoded: Piles of unopened mail and packages were discovered at two locations near each other Thursday morning in Glendale. It is unclear whether the incidents are related.

media:content.media:description: San Pedro, California,-Aug. 20, 2020-A Los Angeles Postal carrier organizes mail to be delivered on Aug. 20, 2020. United States Postal Workers were offered 12 weeks leave due to the coronavirus pandemic, which caused a backlog of mail that needed to be delivered. Many postal carriers were offered overtime. A lack of enough postal carriers is one of the reasons that the United States Postal Service is behind on delivering mail. (Carolyn Cole/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: ICE arrests over 300 in L.A. area during month-long operation
item.dc:creator: Brittny Mejia
item.description: The arrests included people convicted of battery, rape and kidnapping, said ICE, adding that, among those arrested locally, over 100 are now deported.
item.content:encoded: The arrests included people convicted of battery, rape and kidnapping, said ICE, adding that, among those arrested locally, over 100 are now deported.

media:content.media:description: MONTEBELLO, CALIF. -- TUESDAY, APRIL 18, 2017: A Immigration and Customs Enforcement fugitive operations team member Jorge Field outside the Montebello home of a 47-year-old Mexican national in Montebello, Calif., on April 18, 2017. The man refused to come out and the team left. (Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times

item.title: Meatpacking was already a dangerous job for California workers. The pandemic made it worse
item.dc:creator: Jie Jenny Zou , Andrea Castillo, Erin B. Logan
item.description: The shutdown of the Foster Farms plant this week due to coronavirus deaths exposes lapses in one of the most dangerous workplace sectors.
item.content:encoded: The shutdown of the Foster Farms plant this week due to coronavirus deaths exposes lapses in one of the most dangerous workplace sectors.

media:content.media:description: Foster Farms employee Kevin Vera, 28, of Livingston, center, attends a community candlelight vigil with family members at the Max Foster Sports Complex in Livingston, Calif., on Thursday, Sept. 3, 2020. The vigil was held to honor the eight lives lost and hundreds of families impacted by a COVID-19 outbreak at Foster Farms' Livingston plant.

item.title: State of emergency declared as California faces historic heat, possible power outages
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: Gov. Newsom declares a state of emergency as California utilities warn that sweltering conditions and increased demand could result in power outages.
item.content:encoded: Gov. Newsom declares a state of emergency as California utilities warn that sweltering conditions and increased demand could result in power outages.

media:content.media:description: LONG BEACH, CA - SEP. 4, 2020. A blazing sun silhouettes power lines in North Long Beach ahead of a heatwave that is forecast to begin on Saturday, Sept. 5, 2020. The weather event has the potential to set all-time record hot temperatures throughout Southern California through the Labor Day weekend. (Luis Sinco / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: O.C. Democratic leader faces backlash after sharing post praising Ho Chi Minh on Facebook
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Lai
item.description: Jeff LeTourneau resigns as vice chair of the Democratic Party of Orange County after he shared a Facebook post praising Ho Chi Minh
item.content:encoded: Jeff LeTourneau resigns as vice chair of the Democratic Party of Orange County after he shared a Facebook post praising Ho Chi Minh

media:content.media:description: WESTMINSTER, CALIF. -- TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 26, 2019: Vuong "Tom" Nguyen, 65, of Westminster, and a former South Vietnam soldier, leads a group of protestors in singing a patriotic song and using the timing of the Trump-Kim summit in Hanoi as leverage, hundreds of Vietnamese-Americans protest in Little Saigon to boost demand for human rights in their homeland. Photos taken in Westminster, Calif., on Feb. 26, 2019. Protestors marched from Lee's Sandwich to Asian Village and back. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times

item.title: Close-knit Latino family ties bring coronavirus dangers to traditional gatherings
item.dc:creator: Alejandra Reyes-Velarde
item.description: In the U.S., Latinos have been disproportionate casualties of the virus. They are about 39% of the population in California, but Latinos make up 60% of positive cases and 48% of deaths.
item.content:encoded: In the U.S., Latinos have been disproportionate casualties of the virus. They are about 39% of the population in California, but Latinos make up 60% of positive cases and 48% of deaths.

media:content.media:description: Norwalk, CA, September 2, 2020 - Reymond Padilla, a father of 3 and director of the South Whittier Spartans. He has gone to great efforts to keep his team safe from Covid-19. But things get complicated when it comes to family. His daughter lives in a different household. (Robert Gauthier/ Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Dijon Kizzee was 'trying to find his way' before being killed by L.A. deputies, relatives say
item.dc:creator: Leila Miller
item.description: Family members recall a family-oriented man who was hit hard by the death of his mother as a young adult and had been working on finding his way in life.
item.content:encoded: Family members recall a family-oriented man who was hit hard by the death of his mother as a young adult and had been working on finding his way in life.

media:content.media:description: Jonetta Ewing (C), the partner of the late Dijon Kizee who was killed by sheriff's deputies, breaks down while addressing the crowd of activists gather for the weekly Black Lives Matter protest in front of the Hall of Justice in Los Angeles, California on September 2, 2020 - Family members of those killed by law enforcement personnel spoke during the protest, including the partner of Dijon Kizzee, who was killed by sheriff's deputies two nights ago on the evening of August 31 in Los Angeles. (Photo by Frederic J. BROWN / AFP) (Photo by FREDERIC J. BROWN/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Orange County COVID-19 deaths top 1,000 even as new cases start to stabilize statewide
item.dc:creator: Maura Dolan, Paloma Esquivel
item.description: The fallout from the recent summer surge in new coronavirus cases is here: More deaths.
item.content:encoded: The fallout from the recent summer surge in new coronavirus cases is here: More deaths.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - APRIL 21: During the coronavirus global pandemic Sandy Valle, RN, left, Javier Gonzalez, EMT, middle, and Michelle Kim, RN, right, are working inside the triage tent at Martin Luther King, Jr., Community Hospital on Thursday, April 27, 2020 in the Willowbrook neighborhood located in South Los Angeles, CA. The international Medical Corps brought in this tent and it was places outside the Emergency Department at MLKCH. It's for ambulatory patients that have fever, cough, and shortness of breath, potential covid-19 symptoms. Dr. Oscar Casillas says, "We use the large tent to create more space and greater space between patients." (Francine Orr / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Marion Moses, Cesar Chavez confidant and expert on farmworkers' health, dies

item.title: L.A. coronavirus testing centers will close amid extreme heat and Labor Day
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: All drive-through testing sites run by the city will be closed over the 3-day weekend, but a few pop-up testing events will be held Friday and Saturday.
item.content:encoded: All drive-through testing sites run by the city will be closed over the 3-day weekend, but a few pop-up testing events will be held Friday and Saturday.

media:content.media:description: CALABASAS, CA - SEPTEMBER 02, 2020: Laurie Goldfinger, left, attendance secretary for Agoura High School, is given a nasopharyngeal swab test to detect COVID-19 by phlebotomist Jessica Garcia at Arthur E. Wright Middle School in Calabasas. Las Virgenes School District employees on a voluntary basis were given a nasopharyngeal swab test to detect COVID-19 and also had their blood drawn to have it tested for antibodies to determine if they have had the coronavirus infection within the last 2 months. (Mel Melcon / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Britney Spears doesn't want conservatorship case 'hidden away ... as a family secret'
item.dc:creator: Nardine Saad
item.description: In new court documents, Britney Spears supports the #FreeBritney movement and is 'vehemently opposed' to her father sealing her conservatorship case.
item.content:encoded: In new court documents, Britney Spears supports the #FreeBritney movement and is 'vehemently opposed' to her father sealing her conservatorship case.

media:content.media:description: The accusations in Sam Lutfi's case against Britney Spears' parents and her conservators may have been sensational, but the evidence just didn't hold up -- at least in the eyes of the judge, who tossed the suit Thursday before it made it to the jury. Lutfi's lawsuit had accused Britney's mom, Lynne Spears, of libel and her dad, Jamie Spears, of battery. It also accused her conservatorship of failing to pay him a 15% fee on the singer's income during the time he claimed to have been her manager. Full story: Judge boots case against Britney Spears' parents, conservatorship | Britney Spears' dad punched, threatened to kill me, Sam Lutfi says | PHOTOS: Celebrity meltdowns

School officials were allowing no more than 5 students at a time on campus to take home their belongings. (Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Santa Ana embraced a 'defund the police' movement. Then came the police union backlash

item.content:encoded: The experience of activists in Santa Ana who pushed to change funding priorities for police shows the fragile nature of such movements.

media:content.media:description: SANTA ANA, CA - JULY 17, 2020: Standing in front of a downtown mural, former Santa Ana city councilwoman Michele Martinez was involved in the "defund the police" debate only to have it be foiled later by a police union backlash on July 17, 2020 in Santa Ana, California. (Gina Ferazzi / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Skelton: Chaos and incivility ruled the last day of California's legislative session. Blame Zoom
item.dc:creator: George Skelton
item.description: What happened in the California state Senate on the final night of the two-year legislative session Monday was a prime example of machines dispatching decorum and crippling civility.
item.content:encoded: What happened in the California state Senate on the final night of the two-year legislative session Monday was a prime example of machines dispatching decorum and crippling civility.

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this May 28, 2020, file photo, Sen. Holly Mitchell, D-Los Angeles, left, chair of the Senate Budget and Fiscal Review Committee, wears a face mask while standing behind a plexiglass barrier during a budget committee hearing in the Senate in Sacramento, Calif. On Wednesday, July 8, 2020, Secretary of the Senate Erika Contreras announced that, because of an increase in coronavirus cases, the Senate would not return from its summer recess on July 13. The Assembly announced on Monday it would also delay its return after five people who work in the Assembly tested positive for the coronavirus. Speaker Anthony Rendon's Office confirmed Wednesday that number is now at six confirmed cases. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli, File)

item.title: Police officer charged with voluntary manslaughter in death of Bay Area man
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: Jason Fletcher, a San Leandro police officer, was charged with voluntary manslaughter. Fletcher fatally shot Steven Taylor in responding to a shoplifting call.
item.content:encoded: Jason Fletcher, a San Leandro police officer, was charged with voluntary manslaughter. Fletcher fatally shot Steven Taylor in responding to a shoplifting call.

media:content.media:description: Alameda County Dist. Atty. Nancy E. O'Malley announces that her office will charge seven current and former Bay Area police officers in a sexual misconduct scandal involving a woman who now faces a battery charge in Florida.

item.title: L.A. County schools can reopen small in-person classes for their neediest students on Sept. 14
item.dc:creator: Nina Agrawal, Howard Blume, Sonja Sharp
item.description: County health officials said schools may offer services for small groups of students who have individualized education plans, are English language learners, or need assessments or specialized in-school services. The county will not be reopening the waiver program for students in grades TK-6.
item.content:encoded: County health officials said schools may offer services for small groups of students who have individualized education plans, are English language learners, or need assessments or specialized in-school services. The county will not be reopening the waiver program for students in grades TK-6.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUGUST 07: Labels on desks designate where students can sit with respect to social distancing as Los Angeles Unified School District Superintendent Austin Beutner takes a tour of Burbank Middle School with Principal Christine Moore on Friday, Aug. 7, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. As the academic school year looms, preparations have been under way to make campuses safe inside and out, even though the school year will start with distance-learning only because of the surging coronavirus pandemic. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California unemployment agency investigating potential widespread fraud

item.title: A year after Conception boat fire, families mourn: 'This should have never happened'
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton, Marisa Gerber
item.description: A year ago, 34 people died when the Conception dive boat caught fire and sank off Santa Cruz Island. On the anniversary, families gathered to mourn.
item.content:encoded: A year ago, 34 people died when the Conception dive boat caught fire and sank off Santa Cruz Island. On the anniversary, families gathered to mourn.

media:content.media:description: SANTA BARBARA , CA - SEPTEMBER 02: Yadira Alvarez-Peterson holds her 3-year-old daughter Renata Alvarez-Peterson close talking about her 16-year-old daughter Berenice Felipe, who was one of the 34 people who died in the Conception Boat fire one year ago today as family members with friends and officials gathered at Point Castillo at the end of Harbor Walk in the Santa Barbara Harbor where a plaque on a boulder was unveiled to memorialize the 34 lives lost in the Conception Diving Boat fire off Santa Cruz Island on the one year anniversary. Santa Barbara Harbor on Wednesday, Sept. 2, 2020 in Santa Barbara , CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times

item.title: Hair salons can reopen but not malls and shops under new L.A. County plan
item.dc:creator: Jaclyn Cosgrove
item.description: County officials are taking a cautious approach toward reopening amid a generally improving COVID-19 picture.
item.content:encoded: County officials are taking a cautious approach toward reopening amid a generally improving COVID-19 picture.

media:content.media:description: LAWNDALE, CA - SEPTEMBER 01: Nader Salameh, left and his son Gavyn,9, center, from Lawndale, get their hair cut by barbers Anthony Ho, left and Christian Mikhail, center, in the parking lot of Press Box Barber Shop, during the coronavirus pandemic, in Lawndale, CA, Tuesday, Sept. 1, 2020. The barbershop moved their work outside about one month ago, after seeing restaurants around the southbay doing the same. (Jay L. Clendenin / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Commission criticizes 'high-risk' plan to catch suspect, but says LAPD shooting justified
item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector
item.description: A team of Los Angeles police officers crafted a poor plan to catch a homicide suspect but were justified in shooting him after he drew a gun during a pursuit, the Police Commission ruled.
item.content:encoded: A team of Los Angeles police officers crafted a poor plan to catch a homicide suspect but were justified in shooting him after he drew a gun during a pursuit, the Police Commission ruled.

media:content.media:description: A woman who fell out of a moving Los Angeles police car has reached a settlement with the city and officers.

item.title: Video shows sheriff's deputies killing Dijon Kizzee. But questions remain
item.dc:creator: Ruben Vives, Leila Miller, Matthew Ormseth, Luke Money, Alene Tchekmedyian
item.description: A grainy but graphic video obtained by The Times shows a struggle between Kizzee and deputies before he tries to run away and deputies gun him down.
item.content:encoded: A grainy but graphic video obtained by The Times shows a struggle between Kizzee and deputies before he tries to run away and deputies gun him down.

item.title: Meet the California residents stuck behind fire lines after defying evacuation orders
item.dc:creator: Susanne Rust
item.description: Boulder Creek and Bonny Doon, Calif., residents who stayed are reluctant to seek necessities outside their areas for fear of being unable to go home.
item.content:encoded: Boulder Creek and Bonny Doon, Calif., residents who stayed are reluctant to seek necessities outside their areas for fear of being unable to go home.

media:content.media:description: BOULDER CREEK, CA - AUGUST 27: Noah Standridge defied the orders to evacuate his home amid the CZU Lightning Complex fire two weeks ago, he refused to flee. Instead, he stayed behind to knock back the flames encroaching on his hilltop Boulder Creek house, wearing nothing but a t-shirt, shorts and flip-flops. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: L.A. is about to declare a fiscal emergency. That could mean pay cuts for city workers
item.dc:creator: David Zahniser, Dakota Smith
item.description: L.A. is moving ahead with a plan to furlough thousands of city employees. But to do that, officials say, they must first declare that the city is in a fiscal emergency.
item.content:encoded: L.A. is moving ahead with a plan to furlough thousands of city employees. But to do that, officials say, they must first declare that the city is in a fiscal emergency.

media:content.media:description: Council member Bob Blumenfield addresses the Los Angeles City Council in August of 2015.

item.title: Stall tactics. Distractions. Lobbying. How police reform was derailed in California
item.dc:creator: Anita Chabria
item.description: Despite weeks of rhetoric and numerous proposals, California ended its legislative session with only a handful of moderate police reforms. Here's why.
item.content:encoded: Despite weeks of rhetoric and numerous proposals, California ended its legislative session with only a handful of moderate police reforms. Here's why.

media:content.media:description: People with signs and masks reading "I Can't Breath" are seen during a protest over the death of George Floyd in Chicago, Saturday, May 30, 2020. Protests were held throughout the country over the death of George Floyd, a black man who died after being restrained by Minneapolis police officers on May 25. (AP Photo/Nam Y. Huh)

item.title: 'I'm sad, and I'm mad': Killing of Black cyclist by L.A. County deputies sparks outrage, grief
item.dc:creator: Leila Miller, Ruben Vives, Matthew Ormseth, Alene Tchekmedyian
item.description: The fatal shooting by deputies of Dijon Kizzee spurs new outrage in Westmont neighborhood.
item.content:encoded: The fatal shooting by deputies of Dijon Kizzee spurs new outrage in Westmont neighborhood.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - SEP. 1, 2020. Communiy activist Reggie Cole pays a visit Tuesday, Sept. 1, 2020, to the site near the intersection of W. 109th Place and S. Budlong Avenue, where Dijon Kizzee , 29, man was shot and killed by L.A. County Sheriff's deputies. The shootting of Kizzee on Monday afternoon, Aug. 31, 2020, resulted in a standoff between protesters and police that continued into the night. (Luis Sinco / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: A jet pack at LAX? Maybe. Jet packs are very real
item.dc:creator: Samantha Masunaga
item.description: Someone with a jet pack really could have been soaring above Los Angeles International Airport over the weekend, giving pilots a scare.
item.content:encoded: Someone with a jet pack really could have been soaring above Los Angeles International Airport over the weekend, giving pilots a scare.

media:content.media:description: CHICHESTER, ENGLAND - 14th July: David Mayman, (Company Founder of 'Jetpack Aviation in California), flies up the Goodwood Hill displaying his JB11 JetPack at Goodwood on July 14, 2018 in Chichester, England. (Photo by Michael Cole/Corbis via Getty Images)

item.title: Former Bell city councilman arrested on suspicion of killing his wife
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: Danny Harber, 76, who took office after the corruption scandal and indictments obliterated Bell's previous City Council, was arrested Tuesday on suspicion of killing his wife.
item.content:encoded: Danny Harber, 76, who took office after the corruption scandal and indictments obliterated Bell's previous City Council, was arrested Tuesday on suspicion of killing his wife.

media:content.media:description: New Bell City Councilman Danny Harber is sworn in by Assemblyman Ricardo Lara (D-Bell Gardens). See full story
media:content.media:credit: Lawrence K. Ho / Los Angeles Times

item.title: Family of Andres Guardado sues Sheriff's Department, deputies involved in fatal shooting
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: The family of Andres Guardado, an 18-year-old fatally shot by Los Angeles County sheriff's deputies, has sued the Sheriff's Department, the deputy who opened fire and his partner, alleging an unreasonable use of lethal force and a lack of oversight caused "needless loss of life."
item.content:encoded: The family of Andres Guardado, an 18-year-old fatally shot by Los Angeles County sheriff's deputies, has sued the Sheriff's Department, the deputy who opened fire and his partner, alleging an unreasonable use of lethal force and a lack of oversight caused "needless loss of life."

media:content.media:description: GARDENA, CA - JUNE 28: Jennifer Guardado (left), sister of Andres Guardado, who was fatally shot by a sheriff's deputy in Gardena, and other relatives ride in a caravan during the rally seeking justice for Andres Guardado on Sunday, June 28, 2020 in Gardena, CA. (Jason Armond / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Orange County to offer drive-thru voting for election at Honda Center
item.dc:creator: Bill Shaikin
item.description: The Honda Center in Anaheim will be a drive-thru polling site for the November general election.
item.content:encoded: The Honda Center in Anaheim will be a drive-thru polling site for the November general election.

media:content.media:description: Honda Center is photographed on Wednesday, April 26, 2017, in Anaheim, Calif. (AP Photo/Jae C. Hong)

item.title: Following test results dust-up, California to unveil a new COVID-19 reporting system in October
item.dc:creator: Phil Willon
item.description: The state signed a contract with software company OptumInsight Inc. for a database that will handle all COVID-19 testing results, replacing the troubled California Reportable Disease Information Exchange, or CalREDIE.
item.content:encoded: The state signed a contract with software company OptumInsight Inc. for a database that will handle all COVID-19 testing results, replacing the troubled California Reportable Disease Information Exchange, or CalREDIE.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUGUST 12: Cars line up at a COVID19 test site at Dodger Stadium on Wednesday, Aug. 12, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Prosecutors review actions of 4 LAPD officers at protests; LAPD investigates camera use
item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector
item.description: Prosecutors are reviewing allegations of misconduct by four Los Angeles police officers during protests in the city in early June.
item.content:encoded: Prosecutors are reviewing allegations of misconduct by four Los Angeles police officers during protests in the city in early June.

media:content.media:description: Two Los Angeles police officers face charges of repeatedly sexually assaulting four women.

item.title: Prosecutors file assault, robbery charges in attack on transgender women in Hollywood
item.dc:creator: James Queally
item.description: Los Angeles prosecutors will bring charges against two men linked to a brutal attack on a group of transgender women in Hollywood last month.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles prosecutors will bring charges against two men linked to a brutal attack on a group of transgender women in Hollywood last month.
